2339.54.text:

2352.98.text:
about asking questions

2356.22.text:
and being fully present,
I think that sometimes you

2360.45.text:
are going to

2362.46.text:
who don't connect with you,
who are not on your frequency.

2365.04.text:
And I think that knowing that

2368.79.text:
in those moments as yourself
allows you to not get

2372.51.text:
hung up on them, allows

2375.11.text:
And the reality is that
you only have limited time

2377.61.text:
on this Earth, and
so those people who

2379.92.text:
aren't able to meet
you where you're at

2382.75.text:
are oftentimes not
those people that you're

2385.46.text:
You know, I'd say that, again,
in the professional context,

2389.31.text:
seeking to understand people
is this virtuous path where

2393.30.text:
if people aren't going to
meet you all the way at what's

2395.94.text:
your dream, and you're

2398.55.text:
whether it's like Penn
Station or whatever it is--

2400.65.text:
I think that there's
a way that you can

2402.57.text: start earlier on to get there.

2404.98.text:
And so again, I think that just
because someone can't meet you

2407.76.text:
there, like, if you were
to break down again--

2409.72.text:
and you talked about, when we
were chatting right here, like,

2412.26.text:
your perception of
people right off the bat.

2414.61.text:
And I love the idea that
your first question is not

2419.97.text:
It's that for a lot
of people, like, they

2422.13.text:
won't be able to go

2424.27.text:
So what is another

2425.64.text: after that that you can go into?

2427.89.text:
And again, just allowing

2430.38.text:
and what you want to

2434.91.text:

It's, again, just giving

2574.19.text:
to young people and their
browsing and social media

2578.30.text:
One of my favorite
concepts with comparison

2581.78.text:
is the idea that comparison
is the thief of joy.

2585.68.text:
And I just notice this
in any given moment where

2588.05.text:
I find myself comparing
to a competitor,

2592.19.text:
to someone else who's
finding success.

2594.53.text:
And in those moments
where you feel

2597.05.text:
jealousy or angst, whatever it
might be when you're comparing,

2602.46.text:
my first thought there, and
what I've trained myself to do

2604.88.text:
is to realize that that
comparison and that malice,

2608.87.text:
or whatever it might
be, is nothing--

2611.58.text:
it has nothing to
do with that person.

2613.34.text:
It's purely internal, and it
says something about myself.

2616.28.text:
And so I think about
the transformation

2618.17.text:
of comparing to celebrating,
which is what we want to do.

2622.94.text:
Is that if we cannot celebrate
the successes of other people,

2627.38.text:
it only says something about
us and our own insecurities.

2632.72.text:
So it's that shift from
comparing to celebrating.

2635.59.text:
And if we cannot celebrate,
we can acknowledge that

2638.06.text:
it's because of our
own insecurities,

2639.71.text:
and something to be worked

2643.31.text:

2645.56.text:
I think, again,
rather than telling

2647.63.text:
them what to do, the
best thing that we

2650.99.text:
can do with young
people is to ask them

2653.33.text:
why they are doing
things, and to help them

2657.50.text:
And again, how we do that
is with good questions.

2659.58.text:
And I'll revert
back to one that we

2661.04.text:
talked about earlier,
which is, if you

2662.93.text:
have a young person who's

2665.27.text:

2668.42.text: like, why are you doing that?

2670.48.text:
And to see what kind of answer

2672.77.text:
to actually help them

2674.93.text:
for themselves, to see if

2683.19.text:
And so when someone

2685.04.text:

2686.96.text:

resistant for anyone to tell us

2689.21.text:
what to do when we're still

But when we can give

2694.34.text:

2696.56.text:
I think that is probably

2698.78.text:
to help them evaluate
